newsitem.title: FRANCE: Jospin still eyeing stability change talks - aide.
newsitem.headline: Jospin still eyeing stability change talks - aide.

text.p: Prime Minister Lionel Jospin has not softened his desire for more talks on the stability pact intended to keep deficits in check in a single currency, as a French daily suggested, an aide said on Saturday.
"In any case, the prime minister's position is undeniably very far from an article in this morning's press," Jospin aide Manuel Valls told reporters.

An article in Saturday's daily Liberation said Jospin had dropped plans to seek a renegotiation of the pact, which was agreed in Dublin last year and was due to be ratified at a European Union summit in Amsterdam beginning on June 16.
The pact, negotiated by all 15 member states, imposes fiscal restraints on those states participating in European monetary union, due to be launched in 1999.
During his election campaign, Jospin said he did not feel bound by the pact's terms and wanted to renegotiate it with more focus on employment.

There has been growing speculation in financial markets that the new leftist government swept into power in last Sunday's parliamentary election could cause tension with other member states, especially Germany, and possibly delay the launch of the euro.
